Introduction

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is a severe primary immunodeficiency caused by one of several genetic mutations that impair T-cell development with subsequent impaired production of immunoglobulin G (IgG) and immunoglobulin A (IgA) antibodies.  Patients have both cellular and humoral immune deficiency and are at risk for severe, recurrent viral, fungal, and opportunistic (eg, Pneumocystis jiroveci) infections.

Pathogenesis



SCID is caused by one of several genetic mutations that lead to T-cell lymphopenia.  Some SCID mutations also directly impair B and natural killer (NK) cell development.  However, even if B-cell development is not directly impacted, T-cell signaling is required for production of IgG and IgA antibodies (ie, T-cellâ€“induced immunoglobulin class switching).  In these cases, B cells are present but nonfunctional (ie, cannot produce antibodies).  Therefore, in all forms of SCID, cellular and humoral immunity are both impaired.  The most common genetic mutations that cause SCID include:



  • X-linked SCID:  An X-linked recessive mutation in the IL2RG gene is the most common (50% of cases) cause of SCID.  The IL2RG gene encodes the IL-2 receptor subunit gamma (IL2RG), a subunit of the receptor for the cytokines IL-2, IL-4, IL-7, IL-9, IL-15, and IL-21.  A mutation in the IL2RG gene impairs cell signaling and subsequent T- and NK-cell development.  Although B cells are present, they are nonfunctional due to impaired cell signaling.
  • Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency SCID:  An autosomal recessive mutation in the ADA gene is the second most common cause of SCID.  ADA is an enzyme that deaminates adenosine to inosine, an essential step in purine metabolism.  Adenosine is highly toxic to mitotically active cells such as developing lymphocytes.  Therefore, ADA deficiency leads to T-, B-, and NK-cell death and combined cellular and humoral immunodeficiency.
  • JAK3 deficiency SCID:  JAK3 is a member of the Janus family of protein kinases that is associated with the IL2RG.  When cytokines bind the IL2RG, JAK3 mediates signal transduction.  Therefore, an autosomal recessive mutation in the JAK3 gene is functionally similar to a mutation in the IL2RG gene, leading to absent T and NK cells and nonfunctional B cells.


Therefore, the primary risk factor for SCID is a family history of the disorder.  Likewise, a family history of death from infection in early infancy may raise suspicion for SCID.

Clinical presentation and diagnosis



The clinical presentation and diagnosis of SCID typically occurs as follows:

Asymptomatic patients



Clinical presentation:  Patients with SCID are asymptomatic at birth due to transplacental transfer of IgG.



Screening:  Patients are often identified on routine newborn screening via very low or undetectable T-cell receptor excision circles (TRECs), segments of excised DNA that are generated as T cells mature in the thymus.  Because TRECs are not replicated during mitosis, they are markers of T-cell maturation in the thymus.



Confirmatory testing:  Positive newborn screening requires confirmation with quantitative T-, B-, and NK-cell analysis by flow cytometry.  The presence of B and NK cells depends on the underlying genetic mutation, which can be identified by single gene sequencing.

Symptomatic patients



Clinical presentation:  Maternal IgG antibodies wane after the first few months of life and patients develop symptoms before age 1.  Also during this time, patients are exposed to a variety of viral, fungal, or bacterial pathogens.  Therefore, patients typically present with:



  • severe, recurrent infections, including opportunistic pathogens (eg, P jiroveci)
  • chronic diarrhea (due to IgA deficiency)
  • failure to thrive (due to recurrent infections and nutrient loss)


Physical examination:  Findings may be notable for a source of infection (eg, persistent mucocutaneous candidiasis) and absent peripheral lymphoid tissue (eg, tonsils).



Laboratory evaluation:  Complete blood count shows lymphopenia (absolute lymphocyte count â‰¤2,500/mm3, although the standard may vary with age).



Confirmatory testing:  Quantitative T-, B-, and NK-cell analysis by flow cytometry and single gene sequencing are performed to identify the underlying genetic mutation.  All genetic mutations result in cellular and humoral immune deficiency, and quantitative immunoglobulin analysis shows hypogammaglobulinemia.  B cells may be present (as shown on flow cytometry) but are nonfunctional; however, maternal IgG antibodies may be detected in young infants.  Similarly, young infants will not mount an immune response to routine childhood vaccines, but titers may reflect maternal IgG antibodies.



Imaging studies:  Although not required, imaging studies can support the diagnosis.  In SCID, the thymic shadow is absent on chest radiography due to thymic aplasia or hypoplasia.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for SCID includes other primary immunodeficiencies that present with recurrent infections, as follows:

Combined immunodeficiencies



  • DiGeorge syndrome:  This disorder classically presents with craniofacial abnormalities, conotruncal cardiac anomalies, hypoplastic thymus, and hypocalcemia.  Immunodeficiency can also occur and is related to the degree of thymic hypoplasia.  Although complete DiGeorge syndrome can occur, it is rare (<1% of cases) and is characterized by qualitatively and quantitatively normal B cells.  Characteristic syndromic features may not be recognized at birth.
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome:  Similar to SCID, this X-linked recessive disorder is characterized by combined immunodeficiency.  However, patients often present in early infancy with excessive bleeding (eg, following circumcision, umbilical stump detachment) and eczema.

B-cell immunodeficiencies



  • Bruton agammaglobulinemia:  An X-linked recessive disorder, Bruton agammaglobulinemia is characterized by absent B cells and very low or undetectable serum immunoglobulins.  T-cell concentrations are normal, and chest radiograph shows a normal thymic shadow, unlike SCID.  Patients present with recurrent sinopulmonary and gastrointestinal infections.
  • Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID):  This condition is associated with recurrent sinopulmonary or gastrointestinal bacterial infections due to hypogammaglobulinemia; in contrast to SCID, T- and B-cell counts are normal in CVID.

T-cell immunodeficiencies



  • HIV/AIDS:  Perinatally acquired HIV/AIDS can present similarly to SCID with severe, recurrent infections, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive in infancy or early childhood.  However, CD3+ T-cell counts and quantitative immunoglobulin analysis are typically normal.  Maternally derived HIV antibodies may be present in young infants.

Management



SCID is a medical emergency, and immediate interventions are necessary to prevent life-threatening infection while awaiting hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT), including:



  • Strict isolation to minimize exposure to pathogens
  • Prophylactic antimicrobial medications (eg, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, fluconazole)
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin to provide passive humoral immunity
  • Avoidance of live vaccines due to the risk of vaccine-associated infections


HSCT is curative and should be performed as soon as possible following diagnosis.  Retroviral gene therapy is a promising treatment for patients who are not candidates for HSCT (eg, no human leukocyte antigen match).  For example, retroviral vectors insert the gene for ADA into the patient's hematopoietic stem cells, resulting in the production of ADA by all progeny cells.

Prognosis



SCID is fatal in infancy or early childhood if untreated.  However, with prompt diagnosis and HSCT, the prognosis is excellent.  Donor hematopoietic stem cells allow the patient to develop cellular and humoral immunity, reducing the risk of life-threatening viral, fungal, and opportunistic infection.
